channel.title: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?
channel.description: Is there a feature where you can search for a term and replace it with a different term in all the classes, automatically?

item.title: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:12, topic:443012”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=545702.msg4000112#msg4000112 date=1337864863]
Since we are talking about Eclipse I have a question. I know its a super dumb question but I honestly do not know how to do this >.>… Like I know how to do some Java and I’ve opened projects(non RSPS and they were created in netbeans also) before in netbeans but how would I open a Pi in Eclipse? >.>
inb4udumbbruuuh
[/quote]

Just create a project from an existing source… If its not smart enough to use the Netbeans project files, it will at least get the structure set up properly, and adding libraries to the build path is extremely easy.[/quote]
Thanks for the help;p. The server I want to use in eclipse is not from netbeans. I do non rsps related things on netbeans but i’ll give it a try in a minute.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?

item.title: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“Kidpaparoach, post:9, topic:443012”]Since we are talking about Eclipse I have a question. I know its a super dumb question but I honestly do not know how to do this >.>… Like I know how to do some Java and I’ve opened projects(non RSPS and they were created in netbeans also) before in netbeans but how would I open a Pi in Eclipse? >.>
inb4udumbbruuuh[/quote]

Just create a project from an existing source… If its not smart enough to use the Netbeans project files, it will at least get the structure set up properly, and adding libraries to the build path is extremely easy.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?

item.title: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

You can either refactor it, as people said before or, if it’s something more complex, you can use the ctrl+f dialog to do a search&replace (which graciously allows for regex). If you need to do it over multiple files, I don’t believe eclipse explicitly allows you to do this, but you can search for the terms over multiple files, then use ctrl+f for each file listed in the search results pane. This isn’t too bad if there aren’t many files.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?

item.title: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:7, topic:443012”]Netbeans has a nice tool set for this[/quote]rifk

OT - Yes, there is refactoring which is for java variables and other things like that (god damn I know there is a simple word for it, but I’m so tired from my flights I can’t think of it :(), which renames it for your entire project. There is also the replace feature (shown by someone else above) which can be used to replace other things, and can use regex (which I have found to be very handy)

Read full topic

item.title: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

Unless you’re referring to code refactoring, then in that case you would right click the class or variable you want to rename, and then go to refactor.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?

item.title: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?
item.dc:creator: @Jacob5 Jacob_
item.description:
@Jacob5 wrote:

Search Function.

CTRL+H

Go to the last tab and enter whatever you’re searching for inside the text box, then hit replace. After you hit replace it will search and find all terms within files containing the .java file extension. If it finds anything, another box with pop up asking you for the text you want the previous searched text to be replaced with.

Read full topic
item.source: Is there a feature like this in Eclipse?

@Sinned wrote:
